trial_identification.studytitle: Renal Replacement Therapy Intensity in Severe Acute Kidney Injury: An Individual Patient Data Meta-analysis of Randomized Trials
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Renal Replacement Therapy Intensity in Severe Acute Kidney Injury and its Effect on All-cause Mortality and Recovery to Dialysis Independence: An Individual Patient Data Meta-analysis of Randomized Trials

conditions.healthcondition: Severe acute kidney injury requiring renal replacement therapy

interventions.interventions: Higher intensity haemodialysis, a prescribed dose of 35 to 48 ml/kg/h or defined as published in the original publications
interventions.comparator: Standard intensity haemodialysis, a prescribed dose of 20 to 25 ml/kg/h or defined as published in the original publications

primaryOutcome.timepoint: At trial specific follow-up time points.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Renal replacement therapy (RRT) dependence, defined as the proportion of patients who were still RRT dependent at 7, 14, 28, 60 and 90 days, time to recovery to RRT independence
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At trial specific follow-up time points

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: All randomized controlled trials assessing the effects of different doses of renal replacement therapy (RRT) in patients with AKI.

trial_design.statisticalmethods: Individual patient data meta-analysis. Individual patient data from each eligible trial was pooled and all the outcomes were analyzed based on the intention to treat principle, taking all randomized participants into consideration. The effect of different dialysis dosing intensities upon mortality and dialysis outcomes was analyzed using log-binomial regression with a random effects model and random study-by-treatment interaction.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: The George Institute for Global Health
sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Level 10, King George V Building, Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Missenden Rd, Camperdown NSW 2050 Australia

fundingsource.fundingname: Australian National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) project grant
fundingsource.fundingaddress: Level 1 16 Marcus Clarke Street Canberra ACT 2601

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Renal replacement (RRT) dose intensity may affect patient and kidney outcomes in severe acute kidney injury (AKI) but randomized controlled trial (RCTs) have been contradictory for mortality and inadequately powered for renal outcomes. The Investigation, Management, Prognosis, Recovery, Observation, Value and Evaluation of Acute Kidney Injury (IMPROVE-AKI) collaboration brings together investigators from current randomised clinical trials of RRT dose intensity in AKI to perform IPDMA of the effects of RRT dose intensity.
